facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 452 of 1969 is an appeal from the judgment and order dated December 3, 1968 of the Delhi High Court in Civil Writ Petition No. 817 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 452 of 1969. Appeal from the judgment and order dated December 3, 1968 of the Delhi High Court in Civil Writ Petition No. 817 of 1968. C. Misra and M. V. Goswami, for the appellants.

facts.text: The appellants filed a petition under Articles 226 and 227 of the Constitution in the Delhi High Court regarding their admission to the Maulana Azad Medical College, New Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by certificate from a judgment of the Delhi High Court dismissing a petition filed by the appellants under Arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution in the matter of their. admission to the Maulana Azad Medical College, New Delhi, hereinafter called the Medical College

facts.text: The appellants are residents of Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are residents of Delhi. They passed the pre- medical examination of the Delhi University held in April 1968 and obtained 62.5 marks.

facts.text: The appellants passed the pre-medical examination of the Delhi University held in April 1968 and obtained 62.5 marks.

anchor.surface_text: They passed the pre- medical examination of the Delhi University held in April 1968 and obtained 62.5 marks. In June 1968 they applied for admission to the first year M.B., B.S. class at the Lady Harding Medical College, New Delhi but they were number admitted.

facts.text: In June 1968 the appellants applied for admission to the first year M.B., B.S. class at the Lady Hardinge Medical College, New Delhi but were not admitted.

anchor.surface_text: In June 1968 they applied for admission to the first year M.B., B.S. class at the Lady Harding Medical College, New Delhi but they were number admitted. Thereafter they applied for admission to the Maulana Azad Medical College.

facts.text: The appellants applied for admission to the Maulana Azad Medical College after not being admitted to Lady Hardinge.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter they applied for admission to the Maulana Azad Medical College. This companylege, which is a companystituent of the University of Delhi, was established by the Government of India in June 1958.

facts.text: Maulana Azad Medical College is a constituent college of the University of Delhi and was established by the Government of India in June 1958.

anchor.surface_text: This companylege, which is a companystituent of the University of Delhi, was established by the Government of India in June 1958. According to the companylege prospectus, 125 students are admitted annually 15 seats are reserved for schedule caste candidates and 5 for scheduled tribes candidates, 25 of the seats  excluding the seats reserved for Government of India numberinees  are reserved for girl students who are taken on the basis of merit.

facts.text: According to the college prospectus, 125 students are admitted annually to Maulana Azad Medical College: 15 seats reserved for scheduled caste candidates, 5 for scheduled tribes, 25 excluding GOI nominees reserved for girl students on merit.

anchor.surface_text: According to the companylege prospectus, 125 students are admitted annually 15 seats are reserved for schedule caste candidates and 5 for scheduled tribes candidates, 25 of the seats  excluding the seats reserved for Government of India numberinees  are reserved for girl students who are taken on the basis of merit.

facts.text: 23 seats are reserved for categories c to h: sons/daughters of residents of specified Union Territories, Central Government servants posted abroad, cultural scholars, Colombo Plan scholars, Thailand scholars, Jammu & Kashmir State scholars.

anchor.surface_text: According to the numbere 23 seats are reserved for categories  c  to  h  above. The minimum percentage of marks which a candidate seeking admission must have obtained in the aggregate of companypulsory subjects is 55. Now the appellants had obtained 62.5 marks and were domiciled in Delhi.

facts.text: Minimum percentage of marks for admission is 55% in aggregate of compulsory subjects.

anchor.surface_text: The minimum percentage of marks which a candidate seeking admission must have obtained in the aggregate of companypulsory subjects is 55. Now the appellants had obtained 62.5 marks and were domiciled in Delhi.

facts.text: Appellants obtained 62.5 marks and were domiciled in Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: Now the appellants had obtained 62.5 marks and were domiciled in Delhi. According to them they were entitled to admission and would have been admitted but for the reservation of the seats which were filled by numberinations by the Central Government.

facts.text: In 1968, 9 students nominated by Central Government out of 23 reserved seats (categories c to h), these students had less percentage of marks than appellants.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1968 when the appellants sought admission 9 students had been numberinated by the Central Government out of the 23 seats which had been reserved for categories  c  to  h  mentioned above. These students had obtained less percentage of marks than the appellants.

facts.text: Appellants filed writ petition challenging power of Central Government to make nominations, prayed to strike down nominations and admit on merit.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants filed a writ petition in the High Court challenging primarily the power of the Central Government to make the numberinations. It was prayed that these numberinations be struck down and the respondents  Union of India, Medical College, University of Delhi etc.  be directed to admit the -appellants and all other students who were eligible strictly in the order of merit.

facts.text: Delhi High Court dismissed writ petition, upheld authority of Central Government to select for reserved seats, but found two nominations contrary to rules, directed those two seats to general pool from merit list (petitioner 1 No.4, petitioner 2 No.9).

anchor.surface_text: The writ petition was disposed of by a division bench of the High Court. The authority of the Central Government to select candidates for the reserved seats was upheld. It was, however, found that among the nine seats filled in the Medical College by the Government, two numberinations had been made companytrary to the admission rules.

facts.text: High Court directed respondents 1 to 4 to fill two seats immediately from merit list where petitioner No.1 is number 4 and petitioner No.2 is number 9.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, direct the respondents 1 to 4 as follows two seats shall be filled immediately for admission to the first year M.B., B.S. Course of the College from the merit list in which petitioner No. 1 is number 4 and petitioner No. 2 is number 9.

facts.text: In December 1968, appellants filed review petition under s.114 and O.47 R.1 r/w s.141 CPC of judgment dated December 3, 1968, dismissed by High Court on January 27, 1969.

anchor.surface_text: In December 1968, the appellants filed a petition under s. 114 and 0. 47, R. 1 read with s. 141, Civil Procedure Code seeking a review of the judgment and order dated December 3, 1968. This petition was dismissed by the High Court by a detailed order dated January 27, 1969.

facts.text: On February 1, 1969, petition filed under Arts. 133(1)(c) and 132(1) for leave to appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: On February 1, 1969, a petition was filed under Arts. 133  1   c  and 132 1  of the Constitution for leave to appeal to this Court.

facts.text: Medical Courses Admission Committee at its meeting on November 5, 1965 recognised 23 seats reserved for certain categories.

anchor.surface_text: The Medical Courses Admission Committee at its meeting held on November 5, 1965, recognised that 23 seats in the Medical College shall be reserved for certain categories for numberination.

facts.text: Reservation approved by Standing Committee of Academic Council and by Academic Council resolution dated March 3, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: This reservation was approved by the Standing Committee of the Academic Council of the Delhi University and finally by the Academic Council itself by means of a resolution dated March 3, 1966.

facts.text: Prospectus rules relating to admission have statutory sanction.

anchor.surface_text: In the High Court and before us both sides argued on the footing that the rules set out in the prospectus of the Medical College relating to admission have statutory sanction and are number of a purely administrative nature.

facts.text: Petitioner No.1 is number 4 and petitioner No.2 is number 9 in the merit list.

anchor.surface_text: from the merit list in which petitioner No. 1 is number 4 and petitioner No. 2 is number 9. The respondents 1 to 4 shall immediately enquire from the candidates who are above the petitioners in order of merit whether they want the admissions

facts.text: Central Government nominated students to 9 seats out of 23 reserved.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1968 when the appellants sought admission 9 students had been numberinated by the Central Government out of the 23 seats which had been reserved for categories  c  to  h  mentioned above.

facts.text: Two nominations made contrary to admission rules.

anchor.surface_text: It was, however, found that among the nine seats filled in the Medical College by the Government, two numberinations had been made companytrary to the admission rules.

facts.text: University of Delhi is a statutory body incorporated by Delhi University Act 1922 as amended.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that the University of Delhi is a statutory body incorporated by the Delhi University Act of 1922 as amended from time to time.

anchor.surface_text: This would be so because under O. 47, R. 7 the order of the court rejecting the application for review is not appealable. If the appellants desired to challenge that order it could have been done only by asking for leave

anchor.surface_text: On February 1, 1969, a petition was filed under Arts. 133 1 c and 132 1 of the Constitution for leave to appeal to this Court. In the prayer leave was sought against the judgment dismissing the writ petition -as also the order by which the review petition was disposed of. In the certificate, however, in the heading only the judgment dated December 3, 1968 is men- tioned.

arguments.claim: The provision for reservation of seats is unconstitutional as it is not based on any reasonable classification and suffers from the vice of discrimination

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Misra has amplified the first submission-by urging that the reservation of seats for admission to the Medical College was number based on any reasonable classification and suffered from the vice of discrimination.

arguments.claim: Art. 29(2) violated as denial of admission on prohibited grounds

anchor.surface_text: Article 29 2  may be read first. It says, number citizen shall be denied admission into any educational institution maintained by the State or receiving aid out of State funds on grounds only of religion, race, caste, language or any of them.

arguments.claim: Art. 15(1) not violated as no discrimination on grounds of religion, caste, etc.

anchor.surface_text: Under clause  1  of Art. 15 the State cannot discriminate against any citizen on grounds only of religion, caste, sex, place of birth or any of them.

arguments.court_reasoning: Rules do not discriminate on those grounds

arguments.claim: Art. 14 permits reasonable classification if intelligible differentia and rational nexus (citing Dalmia)

anchor.surface_text: As laid down in Shri Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Shri Justice S. Tendolkar Others 1 , Art. 14 forbids class legislation it does number forbid reasonable classification.

arguments.claim: Categories have intelligible differentia: UT residents backward/no med colleges; govt servants abroad face difficulties; scholars reciprocal; J&K peculiar problems

anchor.surface_text: The first group of persons for whom seats have been reserved are the sons and daughters of residents of Union territories other than Delhi. These areas are well known to be comparatively backward...

arguments.claim: Classification has rational nexus to object of imparting medical education from specified sources determined by funding govt

anchor.surface_text: The next question that has to be determined is whether the differentia on which classification has been made has rational relation with the object to be -achieved.

arguments.claim: Distinguish Minor P. Rajendran: district-wise no nexus; here sources properly classified

anchor.surface_text: In Minor P. Rajendran v. State of Madras 1  it has been stated that the object of selection for admission is to secure the best possible material...

arguments.claim: Distinguish Patna HC case: no nexus for univ employees' children; here no favoritism

anchor.surface_text: Nor can the decision of a full bench ofthe Patna High Court in Umesh Ch. Sinha v. V. N. Singh... preferential treatment to the children of these employees would amount to favoritism...

arguments.claim: Central Govt appropriate to nominate due to diverse educational backgrounds; only 9/23 nominated, rest open

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was right in saying that the standards of the examinations passed by them... Moreover this is being done with the tacit approval...

arguments.claim: Appellants have no locus standi to challenge nominations to reserved seats

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the appellants do number have -any right to challenge the nominations made by the Central Government. They do number compete for the reserved seats...

arguments.claim: No obligation to throw invalid reserved seats to general pool

anchor.surface_text: The assumption that if nominations to reserved seats are number in accordance with the rules all such seats... would be thrown open to the general pool is wholly unfounded.

arguments.claim: Certificate under Arts 133(1)(c)/132(1) limited to writ judgment, not review order

anchor.surface_text: In the certificate, however, in the heading only the judgment dated December 3, 1968 is men- tioned. It would appear that the certificate was limited to the appeal against the writ petition.

arguments.claim: Review rejection order not appealable under O.47 R.7; requires Art.136 leave which not sought

anchor.surface_text: This would be so because under 0. 47, R. 7 the order of the court rejecting the application for review is number appealable. If the appellants desired to challenge that order...

arguments.claim: Prospectus rules have statutory sanction under Delhi Univ Act s.30, Ordinance 11

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that the University of Delhi is a statutory body... Ordinance 11 provides that there shall be a Medical Courses Admission Committee.

holdings.text: The certificate under Articles 133(1)(c) and 132(1) is limited to the judgment dated December 3, 1968 dismissing the writ petition and does not cover the review order dated January 27, 1969.

anchor.surface_text: In the certificate, however, in the heading only the judgment dated December 3, 1968 is men- tioned. It would appear that the certificate was limited to the appeal against the writ petition.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Certificate heading mentions only writ judgment; review order requires separate Art 136 leave.

holdings.text: The order rejecting the review application is not appealable under Order 47 Rule 7 CPC and could only be challenged under Article 136, which was not done.

anchor.surface_text: This would be so because under 0. 47, R. 7 the order of the companyrt rejecting the application for review is number appealable. If the appellants desired to challenge that order it companyld have been done only by -asking for leave of this Court under Art. 136 which was never done.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of O47 R7; Art 136 discretionary and not invoked.

holdings.text: The rules in the prospectus relating to admission have statutory sanction under the Delhi University Act and are not merely administrative.

anchor.surface_text: In the High Court and before us both sides argued on the footing that the rules set out in the prospectus of the Medical College relating to admission have statutory sanction and are number of a purely administrative nature.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Common ground between parties; derived from s30 and Ordinance 11 authorizing admissions.

holdings.text: The provision for reservation of 23 seats for specified categories (c to h) is constitutional and does not violate Articles 14, 15(1), 15(4), or 29(2).

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to see how Art. 15 1  can be invoked in the present case. The rules do number discriminate between any citizen on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, place of birth or any of them. Nor is Art 29 2  of any assistance to the appellants.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Satisfies Art 14 twin test: intelligible differentia (backward areas, govt servants abroad, scholars, J&K) with rational nexus to providing medical education facilities funded by Central Govt; no discrimination on prohibited grounds under 15(1)/29(2); not relying on 15(4).

holdings.text: Appellants lack locus standi to challenge nominations by Central Government to reserved seats as they do not compete for those seats.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the appellants do number have -any right to challenge the numberinations made by the Central Government. They do number companypete for the reserved seats and have numberlocus standi in the matter of numberination to such seats.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioners from general/Delhi category; reserved seats for distinct categories; no personal right affected.

holdings.text: There is no obligation to throw reserved seats invalidly filled to the general pool; Central Government may retain or release in larger interest but cannot be compelled by general candidates.

anchor.surface_text: The assumption that if numberinations to reserved seats are number in accordance with the rules all such seats as have number been properly filled up would be thrown open to the general pool is wholly unfounded. The Central Government is under numberobligation to release those seats to the general pool.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reserved seats ring-fenced for specific categories; policy discretion of funding authority.

holdings.text: The High Court erred in examining merits of nominations and directing two seats to general pool, but no further comment as no appeal against that part.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the High Court was in error in going into the question and holding that out of the nine seats filled by numberination two had been filled companytrary to the admission rules and these would be companyverted into the general pool. Since numberappeal has been filed against that part of the order we refrain from making any further observations in the matter.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from no locus standi; procedural bar on expanding scope.

holdings.text: Contention that some nominations invalid for late applications (post Aug 1, 1968) not entertainable as not raised in writ petition, only in review, and appellants have no right to challenge nominations.

anchor.surface_text: Finally Mr. Misra attempted to agitate the question of some of the numberinations being illegal as the candidates who had been numberinated had number applied in time-the prescribed date being August 1, 1968. This companytention cannot be entertained for two reasons.

precedents.citation: Shri Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Shri Justice S. Tendolkar Others 1

anchor.surface_text: As laid down in Shri Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Shri Justice S. Tendolkar Others 1 , Art. 14 forbids class legislation it does number forbid reasonable classification. In order to pass the test of permissible classification two companyditions must be fulfilled,  i  that the classification is founded on intelligible differentia which distinguishes persons or things that are grouped together from others left out of the group and,  ii  that that differentia must have a rational relation to the object sought to be achieved. The .first group of persons for whom seats have been reserved are the sons and daughters of residents of Union territories other than Delhi.

precedents.case_name: Shri Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Shri Justice S. Tendolkar
precedents.cited_proposition: Art. 14 forbids class legislation it does number forbid reasonable classification. In order to pass the test of permissible classification two companyditions must be fulfilled, (i) that the classification is founded on intelligible differentia which distinguishes persons or things that are grouped together from others left out of the group and, (ii) that that differentia must have a rational relation to the object sought to be achieved.

precedents.citation: Minor P. Rajendran v. State of Madras 1

anchor.surface_text: In Minor P. Rajendran v. State of Madras 1  it has been stated that the object of selection for admission is to secure the best possible material. This can surely be achieved by making proper rules in the matter of selection but there can be numberdoubt that such selection has to be companyfined to, the sources that are intended to supply the material.

precedents.case_name: Minor P. Rajendran v. State of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: the object of selection for admission is to secure the best possible material
precedents.cited_holding: classification district-wise had number reasonable relation with the object sought to be achieved

precedents.citation: Umesh Ch. Sinha v. V. N. Singh, Principal, P.M.C. Hospital Ors.  2

anchor.surface_text: Nor can the decision of a full bench ofthe Patna High Court in Umesh Ch. Sinha v. V. N. Singh, Principal, P.M.C. Hospital Ors.  2  be of any avail to the appellants. In that case preferential treatment had been given to the children of the employees of the Patna University in the matter of admission to the Patna Medical College.

precedents.case_name: Umesh Ch. Sinha v. V. N. Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: preferential treatment to the children of the employees of the Patna University lacks reasonable nexus and amounts to favoritism and patronage

anchor.surface_text: The appeal fails and it is dismissed with numberorder as to companyts.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed; appellants' challenge to reservations and nominations rejected; no interference with High Court judgment except noting no appeal against specific part.
